title: Slow Cooker Irish Beef Stew Recipe
description: This Irish beef stew is made in the slow cooker by simmering beef chuck, onions, carrots, and potatoes in a stout-infused broth until super tender.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Soups, Stews and Chili Recipes Stews Irish Stew Recipes Slow Cooker Irish Beef Stew 4.6 (7) 5 Reviews 7 Photos This Irish beef stew is made in the slow cooker for pure comfort food on a chilly day. A little prep time is needed upfront. Don't be fooled by how much onion and garlic are used. It's honestly not too much. Cheers! Submitted by ami_tx Updated on November 25, 2024 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 7 7 7 7 Prep Time: 15 mins Cook Time: 3 hrs 15 mins Total Time: 3 hrs 30 mins Servings: 8 Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 8 servings 3 russet potatoes, diced 1 pound baby carrots 1 large onion, chopped 4 cloves garlic, minced 1 tablespoon olive oil, or to taste 2 pounds beef chuck roast, cubed 1 (16 ounce) bottle stout beer, divided 1 (6 ounce) can tomato paste 1 cup beef broth 1 tablespoon garlic powder 1 tablespoon onion powder 1 tablespoon smoked paprika salt and ground black pepper to taste Directions Place potatoes, carrots, onion, and garlic into a slow cooker. Heat olive oil in a skillet over medium heat. Add beef; cook and stir until evenly browned, about 10 minutes. Transfer beef to the slow cooker with vegetables. Pour 1/4 cup beer into the same skillet and bring to a boil while scraping the browned bits of beef off of the bottom of the skillet with a wooden spoon. Stir in tomato paste; cook until thickened, about 5 minutes. Pour mixture into the slow cooker. Pour remaining beer, beef broth, garlic powder, onion powder, paprika, salt, and pepper into the slow cooker. Cook on Low until potatoes and carrots are easily pierced with a fork, about 8 hours, or on High for 3 to 4 hours. Add Your Photo Photos of Slow Cooker Irish Beef Stew 01 of 07 Photo by  SoupLovingNicole 02 of 07 Photo by  DREGINEK 01/11/2025 Great flavors Followed exactly except I took Soup Loving Nicole’s suggestion of cutting the carrots into smaller pieces. Good suggestion! I was worried there was too much dried spices but, I sprinkled the spices over the meat and veggies before adding in the rest of the broth and beer in Step 4. It was amazing; very flavorful and hearty. Served with dinner rolls. Would make this again! Thanks ami_tx! 03 of 07 Photo by  Soup Loving Nicole 03/17/2024 Made as written and this was good. I recommend halving the carrot amount and cutting them in half. The full amount was too much for my liking and they were too hard to eat with a spoon whole. 04 of 07 Photo by  Marie Watts-Broome 08/30/2020 05 of 07 Photo by  Marie Watts-Broome 08/30/2020 06 of 07 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 03/15/2017 So simple to make with great results. You can never use too much garlic. This easily adapts to a pressure cooker. 07 of 07 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 03/15/2017 So simple to make with great results. You can never use too much garlic. This easily adapts to a pressure cooker. 1 You’ll Also Love Irish Beef Stew 142 Ratings Irish Stout Beef Stew 1 Rating Guinness Irish Stew 29 Ratings Slow Cooker Guinness Beef Stew 45 Ratings Beef and Guinness Stew 1,278 Ratings Leslie's Irish Stew 2 Ratings Beer-Braised Irish Stew and Colcannon 318 Ratings Ballymore Irish Lamb Stew Instant Pot® Irish Beef Stew Slow Cooker Irish Stew 3 Ratings Traditional Irish Stew 135 Ratings Gerry's Irish Beef Stew 13 Ratings Instant Pot Irish Stew 7 Ratings Irish Lamb Stew 584 Ratings Chef John's Irish Stew 123 Ratings Irish Lamb and Potato Stew Recipe 80 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. Stir in tomato paste; cook until thickened, about 5 minutes. Pour mixture into the slow cooker.;Pour remaining beer, beef broth, garlic powder, onion powder, paprika, salt, and pepper into the slow cooker.;Cook on Low until potatoes and carrots are easily pierced with a fork, about 8 hours, or on High for 3 to 4 hours.
